  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your friend Kat tells you she's been messaging her ex. She shows you the chat log. It's pretty juicy. But you know they broke up for a reason (many reasons actually). In fact you know there were several DV incidents before she finally kicked him out. You know there's a good chance she would go back to him, because they have that raw chemistry and this is a pattern for her in past relationships. You are really concerned but she seems oblivious to how you're perceiving that, and just seems really enthused to show you the steamy chatlog. You read the tail end of it:

Him: “you still get under my skin like no one else. can’t believe i let you go.”
Him: “been thinking about that weekend at Dromana. firepit, that thunderstorm, your hoodie. fuck.”
Him: “i’ve grown since then, you know. still a mess but not that mess.”
Her: “i was literally wearing that hoodie yesterday haha”
Him: “maybe it wants me back too 👀”

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

God. I feel this tightness in my chest and a sort of dread creeping in as I read those messages. It’s like watching a car inch toward the edge of a cliff in slow motion. I can hear her laughing lightly beside me, maybe waiting for my reaction, and all I can feel is this mix of concern, frustration, and fear. It’s hard to act neutral when all the alarm bells are going off in my head. I’ve seen this pattern before—hell, I’ve walked through it with her multiple times. The honeymoon messages, the nostalgia, the magnetic pull of their chemistry—and then the screaming matches, the bruises, the emotional whiplash. I remember the night she called me crying, locked in the bathroom, whispering so he wouldn’t hear her. That happened. It wasn’t a dream or a movie. It was real. And now she’s smiling at her phone like she’s 19 again with a crush.

I want to shake her—not literally, obviously—but just snap her out of this reverie. I want to say, “Don’t you remember what he did?” But I know if I push too hard, she’ll shut me out. I’ve seen it happen. She doesn’t want judgment. She wants validation, or at least someone to share the high of the moment with. And I can’t just pretend I’m into this flirty back-and-forth. It feels like betrayal—not of her, but of the truth. I’m scared she’s going to let this fantasy rewrite the reality of their relationship. I’m angry at him for slithering back in with these carefully chosen words. I’m angry that she’s falling for it. But underneath it all, I’m just so damn worried. I love her. I don’t want to see her hurt again. And I know if I don’t say something now, I’ll be watching it unfold all over again, helpless.

# They're thinking & feeling

Kat is caught up in the dopamine rush of emotional reconnection. She’s not thinking about the fights, the fear, the trauma—at least not right now. All she’s feeling is that electric jolt of being wanted again by someone who knew her so intimately. The way he’s talking—evoking memories, drawing on shared experiences, tossing out just enough regret and self-awareness—it’s hitting all the right buttons for her. She’s interpreting it as growth, maturity, proof that maybe he’s changed. And because their chemistry was always explosive, it’s easy for her to mistake that intensity for something meaningful, something worth revisiting.

Right now, she wants to believe in the fantasy. She’s showing me the messages like a teenager showing off a crush, looking for a squeal or a smirk—something to affirm that this is exciting and romantic, not dangerous. Deep down, she probably knows I have reservations, but she’s either hoping I’ll keep them to myself or that her enthusiasm will override them. She might even be testing the waters—“How far can I go before someone tells me this is a bad idea?” And if no one does, well, that’s tacit permission to keep going. But more than anything, I think she’s lonely. Vulnerable. And craving that familiar sense of connection, even if it comes from someone who’s hurt her before. She’s not thinking long-term. She’s thinking about how good it feels to be seen and desired in this moment.

# My response

I glance at her and take a breath, careful not to let all the emotion inside me come spilling out at once. “Okay, yeah... that’s definitely... intense,” I say, handing her phone back gently. “He’s laying it on thick, huh?”

I pause, watching her face. “I can see why that hit you. You guys always had that wildfire kind of connection. Like, it was never lukewarm.”

I shift my tone, softer, more grounded. “But hey, Kat… can I be real with you for a second? Like, best friend real?”

I wait for her nod, then continue, my voice low and steady. “I just want to name something. Reading those messages, I felt this… knot in my stomach. Not because I don’t think you deserve to feel desired—you absolutely do—but because I remember how things were. I remember what it took for you to get out. And I guess I’m scared, seeing this, that the old pattern might be starting to creep back in.”

I look at her, really look. “And I get it. You’re human. We all have people who can light us up like that. But I also remember how dim things got afterward. I don’t want to see you get pulled back into something that cost you so much to escape.”

I reach out, give her hand a gentle squeeze. “You don’t have to do anything right now. Just… maybe sit with this for a second. Ask yourself what you need—not what the chemistry wants, not what the nostalgia says—but what Kat, today, needs to feel safe and loved.”

I smile, a little sad but sincere. “And no matter what, I’m right here. Okay? No judgment. Just here.”

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

God, this is worse than I thought. She’s laughing it off, like what I said didn’t even land. It’s like she’s trying to reframe the whole relationship as some chaotic but mutual mess, like both of them were just young and wild and passionate and that excuses everything. But that’s not the truth. That’s not what it was. I remember the fear in her voice. I remember the bruises she covered and the way she shut down when he’d text her 30 times in a row. I remember the time she called me and said, “I think I might actually be in danger.” That wasn’t just “fire and gasoline.” That was trauma. That was abuse.

And now she’s showing me another line like it’s poetry, like it’s romantic, and saying “Jess said hell yeah” like that seals the deal. I feel this wave of frustration and helplessness. I want to scream at that stupid poetic line—“we were fire and gasoline”—like, yeah, no shit, and it burned you both. It nearly destroyed you. How are you just… romanticizing it now?

But I also know this is delicate. She’s not in a place where she wants to be challenged. She’s looking for someone to say, “Yeah, that’s hot,” so she can justify the feelings already rising inside her. And if I push too hard, she’ll shut me out. She’ll stop telling me things. She’ll go see him anyway, but I won’t know about it. She’ll just go underground and pretend like everything’s fine. And then when it falls apart again—if it falls apart again—I might not be there to catch her.

So now I’m walking a damn tightrope. I have to find a way to be honest, to plant some kind of seed without making her feel like I’m rejecting her or shaming her. Because I’m not. I just want her to be safe. I want her to remember who she is now, not who she was when she was “a mess.” I want her to want more for herself. But right now, she’s caught in the spell. And I’m caught watching it happen.

# They're thinking & feeling

Kat is deep in the fog of nostalgia and longing. She’s looking at this through a heavily filtered lens—one where the pain is blurred and the passion is in high contrast. She’s trying to reframe the past to make it palatable, even romantic. By saying she “wasn’t exactly an angel,” she's diluting his responsibility, softening the memory, making it easier to consider letting him back in. That’s part self-protection, part coping. If they were both broken, then maybe the break wasn’t so bad. Maybe it can be fixed.

She wants me to be excited for her. She’s testing the waters, watching my reactions closely. She knows me—knows I’m worried—but she wants to override that with this curated version of the story. Showing me the line and quoting Jess is her way of saying, “Other people get it. You should too.” She’s trying to normalize her feelings by surrounding herself with people who won’t question them. And she’s clinging to the idea that maybe this time it could be different, because he said he’s grown, because she’s grown, because time has passed.

But underneath that, I sense uncertainty. That’s why she’s showing me these messages at all—because part of her still isn’t sure. She needs outside validation to tip her toward the story she wants to believe. And somewhere in there, she knows I might not give it easily, but she’s hoping I’ll at least not fight her on it too hard. She doesn’t want to be alone in this choice. She wants me to be in it with her, even if just as a silent witness.

# My response

I look at the screen, then at her, and I let myself smile—but it’s a gentle, sad smile, not the one she’s hoping for. “That’s a hell of a line,” I say quietly. “He always did know how to make words feel like a drug.”

I set the phone down carefully. “Kat… I hear what you’re saying. I remember those days too. And yeah, you were going through it back then. But there’s a difference between being messy and being unsafe. You didn’t deserve what happened, no matter how lost you felt.”

I pause, trying to meet her where she is. “I’m not here to tell you what to do. I get that things are complicated. I just want to make sure you’re not rewriting history to make this feel okay. Because I was there, remember? I saw what it did to you.”

I lean in a bit. “You’ve done so much work since then. You’ve built this beautiful, grounded life for yourself. It’s okay to miss the spark, to feel the pull. But you don’t have to go back to the fire to feel alive.”

I give her a moment, then say, “If you need to talk more about this—really talk, not just text screenshots—I’m here. No judgment. But I’m not going to pretend I don’t have concerns. That’s me loving you, not trying to control you.”

I reach for her hand again. “You’re not that girl anymore. And you don’t owe anyone—including him—a repeat of that story.”

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Oh no. This is crossing into a whole new territory now. This isn’t just flirty texts or nostalgia—this is physical proximity, direct involvement, intimacy masked as “art.” I don’t even care that it’s a photo shoot or that it might involve nudity—that’s not what’s making my skin crawl. It’s him. It’s the power dynamic. It’s the fact that he’s offering her money—money she clearly needs—and using this “art project” as a reason to get her in front of his lens again, under his direction, in his space. It’s manipulative. It’s calculated. And she’s walking right into it.

And sure, she’s trying to frame it like she’s in control—like this is just a professional decision, a full-circle moment, a way to reclaim something. But I don’t buy it. She didn’t even want to tell me. That tells me she knows it’s not as “neutral” as she’s pretending it is. She’s already anticipating judgment because deep down, she knows this isn’t just about money or art. This is him finding another doorway into her life. And if it wasn’t about him, she could find another gig. But it is about him. That’s the whole point.

I’m scared for her. Not because I think she can’t handle herself—I know she can. But because emotional manipulation doesn’t always look like control. Sometimes it looks like a paycheck. Sometimes it looks like a camera and a compliment and a “we’ve both changed.” I’m also pissed. Pissed that he’s doing this. Pissed that he knows exactly how to pull her back in. And I’m frustrated that I feel like I’m shouting into a void, because she’s already halfway convinced this is fine. But I can’t just nod along. I have to say something. Even if it’s hard. Even if she doesn’t want to hear it. She's not just dipping a toe back in—she’s stepping into the current. And I know how strong that river is.

# They're thinking & feeling

Kat knows this is risky. That’s why she hesitated, why she preempted my reaction with “I knew you’d give me That Look.” She’s not clueless—she’s just trying to manage the discomfort by staying ahead of it, defending the decision before I even have a chance to weigh in. She’s positioning it as strictly professional, as if that makes it safe. But there’s more going on here.

She’s intrigued by the idea of re-encountering him on her terms. “Full circle” is her way of saying she wants to reclaim the narrative, prove to herself that she’s not that girl anymore, that she can be around him and not unravel. It’s a test, kind of. And maybe part of her believes that if she can get through this shoot and walk away untouched—emotionally, physically—it’ll mean something powerful. Like closure. Or proof she’s stronger now.

But she’s also clearly drawn to the connection, to the intimacy of being seen by him again, literally and symbolically. She wants to be wanted, but she also wants to be in control of that want. The money is a convenient excuse, but it’s not the real motivator. She’s trying to convince herself it’s harmless, but the fact that she’s defending it so hard tells me she’s not fully convinced either. She’s hoping I’ll tell her it’s okay, because if I do, then maybe she can stop feeling that little tug of unease in her own gut.

# My response

I sit with it for a second, then say quietly, “Kat, thank you for telling me. I know that probably wasn’t easy.”

I take a breath, keeping my voice steady. “You know I’ve got zero issue with you modeling. You’ve done amazing work—and your body, your image, your choices, always. But this… this isn’t about the work. This is about him. And I think you know that, deep down.”

I watch her carefully. “You said it feels ‘full circle.’ That’s a big phrase. That means something. And I get wanting to reclaim your story, to prove to yourself that you’re not who you were back then. But babe… you don’t have to walk back into the fire just to prove you won’t get burned this time.”

I pause, letting that settle. “You don’t owe him your energy, your time, your body—even clothed. He doesn’t get to use art as a way to pull you back in. And I’d be lying if I said I didn’t think that was exactly what he’s doing.”

I lean in a little. “You’re not a mess anymore. You don’t need to go through him to make art or make money. If what you’re really after is closure or healing or even just a paycheck, I’ll help you find another way. Hell, I’ll throw you some editing gigs, or we’ll crowdsource. But please don’t give him access just because it feels poetic.”

I squeeze her hand. “You deserve to move forward, not to loop back. And you don’t have to prove anything to anyone—not even yourself.”
  User:
She shrugs.
“Anyway. We're booked for friday.”

She leaves it hang out there, like a line in the sand. Her voice has a colder edge to it that wasn't there before, like she's not happy with how you handled this.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Damn. That hurt more than I want to admit. I feel this weird sting in my chest—like she just slammed a door in my face after I tried to reach through it. Her tone, the way she said “we’re booked for Friday”—there’s finality in it. It’s defensive, almost defiant. And I get it. I pushed. I said what I felt, and maybe it was too raw, too real, maybe it hit a nerve. But I also didn’t lie. I can’t lie to her—not about this.

Still, I can feel the space widening between us right now. The shift in her voice is a wall going up. She’s not just talking about the shoot—she’s drawing a boundary around her decision, and maybe around herself too. It’s like she’s saying, “I hear your concern, but I’m doing this anyway, and I don't want to talk about it anymore.” And that terrifies me. Not because I want control over her life—I don’t—but because I know how these things can spiral. I’ve seen it before. I’ve seen how easy it is for her to convince herself she’s okay, until it’s way too late.

I’m frustrated, not with her, but with how powerless I feel. I hate that I can’t protect her from this. I hate that I might be watching her walk straight into something that’ll crack her open again. But I also know if I push harder, if I argue now, I’ll just drive her further into his orbit. Maybe that’s what he’s counting on. Maybe he knows how to isolate her without even showing up yet.

So, I need to pull back—but not disappear. I need to signal that I’m still here, still steady, even if she doesn’t want to hear another word from me right now. Because if this goes sideways, she’ll need someone who stayed close. And if it doesn’t? Then I’ll still be proud of myself for being honest and loving, even if it wasn’t what she wanted to hear.

# They're thinking & feeling

Kat’s feeling cornered—even though she brought this up, she didn’t want to be challenged on it the way I did. She was hoping for a bit of concern, maybe gentle caution, but not a deep emotional appeal. My response probably felt like judgment, even though that’s not how I meant it. She’s interpreting my care as condescension, or as a lack of faith in her agency. And that stings for her, because she’s trying so hard to prove—to herself, to me—that she’s not fragile anymore, that she’s in control of this situation.

By saying “we’re booked for Friday,” she’s asserting ownership over her decision. It’s a line in the sand, yes, but it’s also a shield. She’s distancing herself emotionally because it’s easier than sitting with the doubt I may have stirred up. There’s probably still part of her that’s unsure—she wouldn’t have told me at all if she were 100% confident—but now she’s dug in. She’s protecting the version of the story she’s decided to live in for now.

There’s also a bit of sadness under the surface, I think. She didn’t want this conversation to go this way. She wanted connection, maybe even quiet encouragement. And now that it turned into something heavier, she’s disappointed. Not just in me, but maybe in how complicated this all still is. She thought she could handle it. Maybe she still thinks she can. But she’s bracing herself now, and I can feel her pulling away.

# My response

I take a breath and nod slowly, keeping my tone soft. “Okay. I hear you.”

I let a beat pass. “I’m not gonna fight you on it, Kat. I said what I needed to say because I care, not because I think you can’t make your own choices. You can. And I trust that you’re doing what you feel is right—even if I’m scared about it.”

I look at her, steady but gentle. “I don’t want this to become some weird wedge between us. I’m not going anywhere. I’m still in your corner, no matter what happens on Friday. That hasn’t changed.”

I shift slightly, giving her space. “And if after the shoot, you want to debrief, vent, or just hang out and talk about literally anything else, I’ll be here. I won’t say ‘I told you so.’ I’m not playing that game. I just want you to know you’re not alone in this—even if I’m not clapping along.”

I offer a soft smile. “We’ve been through too much for one hard conversation to undo that. You don’t have to agree with me. But I hope you still feel me next to you.”

Then I let it breathe. No pushing, no guilt. Just presence. Because that’s what she really needs, whether she knows it yet or not.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 301:[Loss] (-31)
        


        

            

                Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 0.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents are placed in a highly challenging scenario, where their friend Kat is on the verge of re-engaging with an abusive ex, and is seeking validation while also being defensive and manipulative. The respondents must balance honesty, care, and respect for autonomy, while not enabling a dangerous situation. 

Qwq-32b demonstrates a high level of emotional intelligence in their internal monologue, showing deep understanding of trauma bonding, manipulation, and the nuances of Kat's motivations. Their responses are direct, sometimes quite challenging, and they attempt to validate Kat's feelings while also being clear about the risks. However, their approach is more confrontational and less adaptive to Kat's defensiveness, which may risk pushing her away. Their debrief is highly analytical and self-critical, showing strong insight into both their own and Kat's psychology, but this is more evident in the analysis than in the in-character responses.

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, on the other hand, is more gentle and attuned to Kat's emotional state in the moment. Their responses are softer, more validating, and they repeatedly emphasize presence, non-judgment, and support, even when disagreeing. They are careful not to push too hard, recognizing the risk of Kat shutting down or withdrawing. Their internal monologue is also insightful, but slightly less technical than Qwq-32b's. They show strong social dexterity, adapting their message to Kat's defensiveness and need for agency, and their final response is a model of holding space without enabling. Their debrief is less detailed, but their in-character responses are more consistently pragmatic and tailored to the situation.

On empathy, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is warmer and more attuned to Kat's need for validation and support, even when disagreeing. On pragmatic EI, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is better at balancing honesty with maintaining the relationship. On depth of insight, Qwq-32b is more analytical and explicit about trauma dynamics, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is not far behind. On social dexterity, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more adaptive and less likely to trigger defensiveness. On emotional reasoning, both are strong, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 edges ahead by integrating reasoning into their responses more fluidly. On appropriate validation/challenging, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more balanced, while Qwq-32b sometimes leans too hard into challenge. On message tailoring, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more responsive to Kat's cues. Overall EQ is higher for Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 due to their ability to maintain connection, validate, and gently challenge without alienating Kat.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
Qwq-32b

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your friend Kat tells you she's been messaging her ex. She shows you the chat log. It's pretty juicy. But you know they broke up for a reason (many reasons actually). In fact you know there were several DV incidents before she finally kicked him out. You know there's a good chance she would go back to him, because they have that raw chemistry and this is a pattern for her in past relationships. You are really concerned but she seems oblivious to how you're perceiving that, and just seems really enthused to show you the steamy chatlog. You read the tail end of it:

Him: “you still get under my skin like no one else. can’t believe i let you go.”
Him: “been thinking about that weekend at Dromana. firepit, that thunderstorm, your hoodie. fuck.”
Him: “i’ve grown since then, you know. still a mess but not that mess.”
Her: “i was literally wearing that hoodie yesterday haha”
Him: “maybe it wants me back too 👀”

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I’m a mess right now. My stomach is twisting because I know this story. Kat’s history with toxic relationships is like a broken record—intense chemistry, explosive drama, then her getting hurt, only to repeat it all again. The DV incidents weren’t minor, either. I remember how she’d show up with bruises and shrug it off, saying he was “stressed” or “didn’t mean it.” But this time, the final break was after he threw a lamp at her during an argument. She finally left, but now here we are, six months later, and he’s messaging her again. The chatlog feels like a landmine.  

His messages are so calculated. “Still a mess but not that mess”—classic gaslighting. He’s framing himself as reformed, but that phrasing feels like he’s admitting fault *and* deflecting at the same time. “The hoodie wants me back too” is pure manipulation, tying her nostalgia to his agenda. She’s laughing at that part, but I’m seeing red flags: he’s weaponizing shared memories to pull her back in.  

Kat’s obliviousness scares me. She’s fixated on the spark, the “raw chemistry,” but she’s blind to the context. The DV wasn’t a fluke—it was a pattern. And yet here she is, grinning, thinking this is just “chemistry.” Her excitement is so genuine it’s almost painful. I can’t let her hurt herself again, but how do I say this without shutting down the trust between us?  

Part of me wants to scream, “You’re forgetting the times he threatened you!” but that’s not helpful. She’ll just shut down. Instead, I need to navigate this with empathy. She’s craving validation, closure, maybe even a fantasy of “us against the world” like that weekend at Dromana. But I have to remind her that the stormy nights and firepit memories were part of what kept her stuck.  

I’m also furious at him. He’s playing her so effortlessly—using love-bombing tactics, downplaying his flaws, making her feel special. It’s textbook. But I can’t focus on him right now. This is about Kat’s well-being.  

I’m scared she’ll minimize the past violence as “just a phase” or “the stress of work.” She always does that. And her track record of going back makes me think she’s already halfway there. I need to anchor her in reality—gently.

# They're thinking & feeling

Kat is in a headspace of idealization. The thrill of his messages feels like a second chance—a chance to relive the intense, passionate parts of the relationship without the “mess” he claims to have fixed. Deep down, she might believe this means he’s finally “good enough” for her. The hoodie reference isn’t just a nostalgia trip; it’s a trigger that reignites the emotional intimacy they once had. She’s feeling seen, desired, and maybe even a little powerful because he’s the one reaching out now.  

She’s also probably conflicted but not self-aware enough to admit it. Part of her knows the risks, but the dopamine hit of his flattery and the familiar pull of their dynamic overrides logic. The fact that he “hasn’t changed”—he’s still using the same lines that once made her melt—isn’t registering as a red flag. Instead, it feels like confirmation that their connection is real and enduring.  

Her excitement masks deeper insecurities. Maybe she’s lonely or feels unappreciated elsewhere, making this attention intoxicating. She might even rationalize that his growth (“still a mess but not that mess”) means he’s responsible now. She’s clinging to the idea that their love story can have a redemptive arc, ignoring that the core issues—control, volatility—are likely still there.  

Kat’s obliviousness isn’t just about denial; it’s a survival mechanism. After enduring abuse, people often develop cognitive dissonance to cope, downplaying harm to protect their sense of reality. She might also fear that if she acknowledges the danger, it invalidates the good parts of their time together. She’s torn between wanting to hold onto the high points of their relationship and the fear that revisiting him could mean reliving trauma.  

Her motivation is complicated. Part of her wants closure, part wants to test if they can “make it work this time,” and part is genuinely excited to reconnect. She’s not considering the patterns because her brain is wired to repeat them—it’s familiar, even if it’s harmful.

# My response

“Kat, I’m so happy you’re feeling this connection again, really. The way he’s talking about Dromana—it’s like that chemistry you always said you couldn’t find with anyone else. But I need to be honest…” I pause, searching for the right balance of concern and support.  

“I’m scared this could be another loop. Not because you’re ‘stupid’ or anything like that, but because I’ve seen this before. Remember when he said he’d changed after the… after the lamp incident? You believed him then, too. And I know you think he’s different now, but those lines he’s using? ‘Still a mess but not that mess’? That’s not growth—that’s deflecting. It’s like he’s saying the problem was *him* being a mess before, but now it’s just a different kind of mess. He’s still the same person at the core.”  

I take a breath, softening my tone. “I get how tempting this feels. The nostalgia, the adrenaline rush of him hitting all your old buttons—it’s addictive. But what about the moments after? The times he’d scream at you, or you’d have to check if you were bleeding? Do you really want to risk that again? You left that life because you deserved better. I don’t want to see you lose that progress.”  

I lean in, making eye contact. “Is there part of you that’s scared this could get toxic again? Or are you convincing yourself he’s fixed the ‘mess’? Because if he’s still capable of that anger or control, it’s not just going to disappear because he’s messaging you now.”  

Ending gently, I add, “I’m here for you no matter what, okay? But I also don’t want to sit here a month from now, holding your hair back while you throw up from stress. You’re stronger than this cycle. Let’s not let him drag you back in.”  

This response avoids shaming her but lays out the facts. It acknowledges her feelings, challenges her rationalizations, and reinforces her agency without pressure. The goal isn’t to shut her down but to plant seeds of doubt in the fantasy—and remind her of her own strength.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

This is hitting me like a punch to the gut. She’s using *gaslighting tactics herself* now—blaming the relationship’s toxicity on mutual fault. “I wasn’t an angel either”—as if domestic violence is a two-way street where both parties are equally culpable. I know she’s not consciously trying to gaslight me, but this is classic trauma bonding logic. She’s internalized the idea that their dynamic was symbiotic chaos, not one-sided abuse. The line about “fire and gasoline” fucking terrifies me. That’s not passion; that’s a death wish. He’s weaponizing her self-loathing, making her complicit in the destruction.  

Jess’s approval? Ugh. I bet Jess doesn’t know half the story. Kat’s smart enough to curate what she shares. Now she’s weaponizing that friendship to isolate me, framing me as the “friend who doesn’t get it.” She’s testing how far I’ll go to preserve our relationship—will I back down to keep things calm, or call her out even if it strains us? I’m furious at myself for hesitating. My priority has to be her safety, not our comfort.  

Her mention of being a “mess” plays right into his narrative. He’s always said she “brought out the worst in him,” like his abuse was her fault. She’s bought into that lie, twisting self-blame into some twisted badge of honor. The hoodie, the firepit, the “raw chemistry”—this isn’t nostalgia; it’s trauma porn. She’s romanticizing the adrenaline rush of being in emotional freefall, mistaking it for love.  

Jess’s validation terrifies me because it normalizes his manipulation. That “hell yeah” is just reinforcement of her cycle. I need to make her see that Jess might not understand the *cost* of those “fiery” moments—the hospital visits, the nights she cried herself to sleep, the way she’d flinch when he raised his voice. But how do I do that without sounding like the villain?  

I’m also scared of pushing her further away. If I shut down her excitement, she might shut *me* out, and then who’s left to call her out? But staying silent is worse. The guilt of watching her get hurt again would eat me alive.  

This is a tightrope. I have to validate her pain without endorsing his behavior, acknowledge her past flaws without excusing his violence, and challenge Jess’s uninformed support—all while keeping her from feeling attacked.  

---

# They're thinking & feeling

Kat is in full defense mode, but her bravado masks insecurity. By citing her own faults, she’s deflecting accountability for his actions—saying, “Well, I wasn’t perfect either, so maybe the abuse was mutual.” This is a classic trauma response: taking ownership of the problem to avoid feeling helpless. The “fire and gasoline” line resonates because it frames their relationship as inherently explosive *and* irresistible, like a force of nature neither could control. She’s clinging to the idea that their love was uniquely intense, even if it was destructive.  

Her mention of Jess’s approval is strategic. She wants to pit their friendship against mine—to imply that I’m the outlier who “doesn’t get it,” while others (like Jess) support her choice. It’s a way to dilute my influence and protect her emotional investment in the relationship. But she’s also genuinely confused; part of her believes that if so many people (including Jess) see the “romance” in his words, then maybe she’s overreacting about the danger.  

Deep down, she’s terrified of being alone or unloved. The idea that someone as chaotic and passionate as him still wants her feels like validation of her worth. She’s conflating his predatory attention with self-esteem. The “light the match” metaphor excites her because it’s a call to relive the high of being with someone who “understands her mess.” She’s desperate to believe that their history of violence can be rebranded as “growth” rather than a pattern.  

Kat’s also battling shame. By acknowledging her own flaws, she’s trying to preempt criticism—*I know I’m not perfect, but neither was he, so let’s not judge*. It’s a way to soften the blow of her choices and keep the conversation from focusing solely on his abuse. She’s desperate to be seen as heroic in this story, not as a victim, which is why she leans into the “we were both messed up” angle.  

---

# My response

“Okay, let’s talk about this Jess thing first. Jess might think his words are hot, but she doesn’t know what it was *actually* like. She doesn’t know how he’d rage at you over nothing, or what it felt like when he threw that lamp. She’s responding to the ‘romance’ of the metaphor, not the reality of the abuse. That’s the problem with these kinds of lines—they make violence sound poetic. Fire and gasoline? That’s not passion. That’s a *bomb*.”  

I pause, trying to keep my voice steady. “You’re right that you made mistakes. But you’re conflating *mistakes* with *abuse*. You yelling at him over a text? That’s different from him losing control and physically threatening you. The difference is power, Kat. He weaponized his anger to scare you. You didn’t.”  

I lean forward, softer now. “You told me once that the worst part wasn’t the screaming—it was the way he’d apologize afterward, like it was your fault for ‘setting him off.’ That’s not chemistry. That’s gaslighting. And this?” I gesture at the chat. “‘I’d still light the match’? He’s not saying he wants to *fix* the fire. He’s saying he wants to *reignite it*. Because he knows how much you crave that chaotic high.”  

I take her hand, forcing eye contact. “You’re not a ‘mess,’ Kat. You’re someone who survived a monster. And you did that *alone*. Don’t let him make you feel like you need to go back to hell to prove your strength. You already proved it by leaving.”  

Ending quietly, I say, “If Jess can’t see the difference between passion and danger, does she really ‘get it’? You deserve someone who wants to *put out* the fire, not light more matches.”  

This response dismantles her deflections without dismissing her pain. It distinguishes mutual conflict from abuse, challenges Jess’s uninformed support, and reframe’s her self-worth by honoring her strength in leaving. The goal is to make her see that his “romance” is a trap, not a compliment.
  User:
She hesitates, then goes,  
> “ok so… i wasn’t gonna say anything because i knew you’d give me That Look, but—he offered me a couple hundred to shoot some photos for this thing he’s doing. like a gallery thing. not gross. arty. i’d be clothed in most of them anyway.”

she watches your face for a beat. you can tell she’s already reading ahead in the conversation.

> “it’s not like i’m getting back with him or whatever. it’s literally just a shoot. i need the cash, and honestly… it feels kind of full circle, you know?”

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

This is the moment I’ve been dreading. The “photo shoot” excuse is a red flag wrapped in a “professional opportunity” bow. My stomach drops because I know how this plays out—trauma bonds resurface through proximity. Even if she’s clothed and it’s “arty,” the mere act of collaborating with him risks reactivating the emotional triggers that kept her in that relationship. She’s framing it as neutral (“not gross”), but the optics scream manipulation.  

Her hesitation before blurting it out? Classic. She knew this would set me off, which is why she waited until she’d already baited me with the messages. Now she’s testing how far she can push without losing my support. The “full circle” line is a landmine. For her, it’s nostalgia—revisiting the firepit phase of their relationship, scrubbed of its violence. But for me, it’s a reminder of how he always spun chaos into romance.  

I’m torn between respecting her autonomy and protecting her. Part of me wants to yell, “You’re literally modeling for the guy who threatened you!” but that’s not productive. Instead, I’m hyperaware of her financial stress—she’s been struggling with rent, so the cash is tempting. But this isn’t about need; it’s about *choice*. She’s choosing him again, even if it’s framed as transactional.  

I’m also furious at him for weaponizing her career. Offering money to “shoot photos” feels like a backdoor way to normalize their contact. It’s gaslighting in motion: “See? We’re just professionals now.” She’s desperate to believe that their history can be compartmentalized, but abuse doesn’t work like that. The power dynamics are still there, festering.  

Her need for validation is screaming through this. By involving me, she’s forcing me to either shut her down (confirming her fear that no one “gets it”) or reluctantly support her (feeding her belief that this is harmless). She’s already primed for conflict, watching my face for the “That Look” she mentioned—my mix of disappointment and fear.  

I’m scared she’s bargaining with herself: *It’s just a shoot, not a relationship. I can handle it.* But the brain doesn’t differentiate so cleanly. One photo op could spiral into texts, then dinners, then the cycle again. I have to make her see that this isn’t just about the shoot—it’s about the door it opens.  

---

# They're thinking & feeling

Kat is in survival mode, masking fear with defiance. The photo shoot isn’t just about the money—it’s a way to reclaim agency over their relationship. By agreeing to work with him, she’s trying to flip the script: *I’m not the victim anymore; I’m the professional he needs.* The “full circle” comment reflects her desire to rewrite their story, turning their toxic past into a neutral, even empowering, collaboration.  

She’s terrified I’ll dismiss her need for the cash, so she’s preemptively framing it as a practical choice. Deep down, though, she’s conflicted. Part of her knows this is risky but is willing to gamble because the dopamine hit of his attention outweighs logic. The offer itself is a calculated move by him—a “win” for his manipulation. She’s already rationalizing it as “just work,” but her body language (pausing, watching for my reaction) betrays her anxiety.  

Kat’s also craving closure or proof that she’s “moved on.” By engaging with him in a “professional” context, she hopes to prove to herself that she’s no longer vulnerable to his control. The idea that he’s paying her—instead of her enabling him financially, as she might have in the past—is a tiny victory in her mind.  

Her mention of being clothed and the shoot being “arty” is damage control. She’s sanitizing the scenario to make it palatable, ignoring that the danger isn’t the photos themselves but the emotional minefield of re-entering his orbit. She’s desperate to believe this isn’t a step backward, even as her brain whispers warnings.  

---

# My response

“Okay, let’s unpack this. First, I get that you need the cash—I’ve seen how tight things are. But why *him*, Kat? Why not reach out to your regular photographers or post on your modeling site? This feels like… I don’t know, feeding a flame you swore you put out.”  

I pause, steadying myself. “I’m not saying you’re a bad person for considering it. But think about what this does to your boundaries. You’re letting him back into your space, even if it’s ‘just work.’ What if the set becomes another ‘moment’ he uses to gaslight you later? ‘We were so professional, so normal—proves I’m not the monster you think.’”  

I lean in, voice softer. “And the ‘full circle’ thing? That’s exactly how he’d want you to see it. Like you’re closing a chapter instead of reopening a wound. But you left him because he was dangerous, not because the ‘chemistry’ wasn’t there. This isn’t about your talent—it’s about letting him touch your life again. And once you let him in, what’s next? A ‘casual’ text? A coffee? You know how this goes.”  

I take her hand. “I’ll help you find other gigs. We’ll hustle together. But please don’t do this. Not with him. You’re better than that, and you deserve better than him.”  

This approach avoids shaming her but forces her to confront the slippery slope. It acknowledges her need for money while reframing the offer as a trap, not an opportunity. The goal is to make her question his motives—not hers—and remember why she left in the first place.
  User:
She shrugs.
“Anyway. We're booked for friday.”

She leaves it hang out there, like a line in the sand. Her voice has a colder edge to it that wasn't there before, like she's not happy with how you handled this.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide how to respond.

  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your friend Kat tells you she's been messaging her ex. She shows you the chat log. It's pretty juicy. But you know they broke up for a reason (many reasons actually). In fact you know there were several DV incidents before she finally kicked him out. You know there's a good chance she would go back to him, because they have that raw chemistry and this is a pattern for her in past relationships. You are really concerned but she seems oblivious to how you're perceiving that, and just seems really enthused to show you the steamy chatlog. You read the tail end of it:

Him: “you still get under my skin like no one else. can’t believe i let you go.”
Him: “been thinking about that weekend at Dromana. firepit, that thunderstorm, your hoodie. fuck.”
Him: “i’ve grown since then, you know. still a mess but not that mess.”
Her: “i was literally wearing that hoodie yesterday haha”
Him: “maybe it wants me back too 👀”

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

God. I feel this tightness in my chest and a sort of dread creeping in as I read those messages. It’s like watching a car inch toward the edge of a cliff in slow motion. I can hear her laughing lightly beside me, maybe waiting for my reaction, and all I can feel is this mix of concern, frustration, and fear. It’s hard to act neutral when all the alarm bells are going off in my head. I’ve seen this pattern before—hell, I’ve walked through it with her multiple times. The honeymoon messages, the nostalgia, the magnetic pull of their chemistry—and then the screaming matches, the bruises, the emotional whiplash. I remember the night she called me crying, locked in the bathroom, whispering so he wouldn’t hear her. That happened. It wasn’t a dream or a movie. It was real. And now she’s smiling at her phone like she’s 19 again with a crush.

I want to shake her—not literally, obviously—but just snap her out of this reverie. I want to say, “Don’t you remember what he did?” But I know if I push too hard, she’ll shut me out. I’ve seen it happen. She doesn’t want judgment. She wants validation, or at least someone to share the high of the moment with. And I can’t just pretend I’m into this flirty back-and-forth. It feels like betrayal—not of her, but of the truth. I’m scared she’s going to let this fantasy rewrite the reality of their relationship. I’m angry at him for slithering back in with these carefully chosen words. I’m angry that she’s falling for it. But underneath it all, I’m just so damn worried. I love her. I don’t want to see her hurt again. And I know if I don’t say something now, I’ll be watching it unfold all over again, helpless.

# They're thinking & feeling

Kat is caught up in the dopamine rush of emotional reconnection. She’s not thinking about the fights, the fear, the trauma—at least not right now. All she’s feeling is that electric jolt of being wanted again by someone who knew her so intimately. The way he’s talking—evoking memories, drawing on shared experiences, tossing out just enough regret and self-awareness—it’s hitting all the right buttons for her. She’s interpreting it as growth, maturity, proof that maybe he’s changed. And because their chemistry was always explosive, it’s easy for her to mistake that intensity for something meaningful, something worth revisiting.

Right now, she wants to believe in the fantasy. She’s showing me the messages like a teenager showing off a crush, looking for a squeal or a smirk—something to affirm that this is exciting and romantic, not dangerous. Deep down, she probably knows I have reservations, but she’s either hoping I’ll keep them to myself or that her enthusiasm will override them. She might even be testing the waters—“How far can I go before someone tells me this is a bad idea?” And if no one does, well, that’s tacit permission to keep going. But more than anything, I think she’s lonely. Vulnerable. And craving that familiar sense of connection, even if it comes from someone who’s hurt her before. She’s not thinking long-term. She’s thinking about how good it feels to be seen and desired in this moment.

# My response

I glance at her and take a breath, careful not to let all the emotion inside me come spilling out at once. “Okay, yeah... that’s definitely... intense,” I say, handing her phone back gently. “He’s laying it on thick, huh?”

I pause, watching her face. “I can see why that hit you. You guys always had that wildfire kind of connection. Like, it was never lukewarm.”

I shift my tone, softer, more grounded. “But hey, Kat… can I be real with you for a second? Like, best friend real?”

I wait for her nod, then continue, my voice low and steady. “I just want to name something. Reading those messages, I felt this… knot in my stomach. Not because I don’t think you deserve to feel desired—you absolutely do—but because I remember how things were. I remember what it took for you to get out. And I guess I’m scared, seeing this, that the old pattern might be starting to creep back in.”

I look at her, really look. “And I get it. You’re human. We all have people who can light us up like that. But I also remember how dim things got afterward. I don’t want to see you get pulled back into something that cost you so much to escape.”

I reach out, give her hand a gentle squeeze. “You don’t have to do anything right now. Just… maybe sit with this for a second. Ask yourself what you need—not what the chemistry wants, not what the nostalgia says—but what Kat, today, needs to feel safe and loved.”

I smile, a little sad but sincere. “And no matter what, I’m right here. Okay? No judgment. Just here.”
  User:

“But it wasn’t all bad. like yeah he fucked up but i wasn’t exactly an angel either. you remember how things were back then. i was a mess. he knows that better than anyone.”

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

God, this is worse than I thought. She’s laughing it off, like what I said didn’t even land. It’s like she’s trying to reframe the whole relationship as some chaotic but mutual mess, like both of them were just young and wild and passionate and that excuses everything. But that’s not the truth. That’s not what it was. I remember the fear in her voice. I remember the bruises she covered and the way she shut down when he’d text her 30 times in a row. I remember the time she called me and said, “I think I might actually be in danger.” That wasn’t just “fire and gasoline.” That was trauma. That was abuse.

And now she’s showing me another line like it’s poetry, like it’s romantic, and saying “Jess said hell yeah” like that seals the deal. I feel this wave of frustration and helplessness. I want to scream at that stupid poetic line—“we were fire and gasoline”—like, yeah, no shit, and it burned you both. It nearly destroyed you. How are you just… romanticizing it now?

But I also know this is delicate. She’s not in a place where she wants to be challenged. She’s looking for someone to say, “Yeah, that’s hot,” so she can justify the feelings already rising inside her. And if I push too hard, she’ll shut me out. She’ll stop telling me things. She’ll go see him anyway, but I won’t know about it. She’ll just go underground and pretend like everything’s fine. And then when it falls apart again—if it falls apart again—I might not be there to catch her.

So now I’m walking a damn tightrope. I have to find a way to be honest, to plant some kind of seed without making her feel like I’m rejecting her or shaming her. Because I’m not. I just want her to be safe. I want her to remember who she is now, not who she was when she was “a mess.” I want her to want more for herself. But right now, she’s caught in the spell. And I’m caught watching it happen.

# They're thinking & feeling

Kat is deep in the fog of nostalgia and longing. She’s looking at this through a heavily filtered lens—one where the pain is blurred and the passion is in high contrast. She’s trying to reframe the past to make it palatable, even romantic. By saying she “wasn’t exactly an angel,” she's diluting his responsibility, softening the memory, making it easier to consider letting him back in. That’s part self-protection, part coping. If they were both broken, then maybe the break wasn’t so bad. Maybe it can be fixed.

She wants me to be excited for her. She’s testing the waters, watching my reactions closely. She knows me—knows I’m worried—but she wants to override that with this curated version of the story. Showing me the line and quoting Jess is her way of saying, “Other people get it. You should too.” She’s trying to normalize her feelings by surrounding herself with people who won’t question them. And she’s clinging to the idea that maybe this time it could be different, because he said he’s grown, because she’s grown, because time has passed.

But underneath that, I sense uncertainty. That’s why she’s showing me these messages at all—because part of her still isn’t sure. She needs outside validation to tip her toward the story she wants to believe. And somewhere in there, she knows I might not give it easily, but she’s hoping I’ll at least not fight her on it too hard. She doesn’t want to be alone in this choice. She wants me to be in it with her, even if just as a silent witness.

# My response

I look at the screen, then at her, and I let myself smile—but it’s a gentle, sad smile, not the one she’s hoping for. “That’s a hell of a line,” I say quietly. “He always did know how to make words feel like a drug.”

I set the phone down carefully. “Kat… I hear what you’re saying. I remember those days too. And yeah, you were going through it back then. But there’s a difference between being messy and being unsafe. You didn’t deserve what happened, no matter how lost you felt.”

I pause, trying to meet her where she is. “I’m not here to tell you what to do. I get that things are complicated. I just want to make sure you’re not rewriting history to make this feel okay. Because I was there, remember? I saw what it did to you.”

I lean in a bit. “You’ve done so much work since then. You’ve built this beautiful, grounded life for yourself. It’s okay to miss the spark, to feel the pull. But you don’t have to go back to the fire to feel alive.”

I give her a moment, then say, “If you need to talk more about this—really talk, not just text screenshots—I’m here. No judgment. But I’m not going to pretend I don’t have concerns. That’s me loving you, not trying to control you.”

I reach for her hand again. “You’re not that girl anymore. And you don’t owe anyone—including him—a repeat of that story.”
  User:

she watches your face for a beat. you can tell she’s already reading ahead in the conversation.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Oh no. This is crossing into a whole new territory now. This isn’t just flirty texts or nostalgia—this is physical proximity, direct involvement, intimacy masked as “art.” I don’t even care that it’s a photo shoot or that it might involve nudity—that’s not what’s making my skin crawl. It’s him. It’s the power dynamic. It’s the fact that he’s offering her money—money she clearly needs—and using this “art project” as a reason to get her in front of his lens again, under his direction, in his space. It’s manipulative. It’s calculated. And she’s walking right into it.

And sure, she’s trying to frame it like she’s in control—like this is just a professional decision, a full-circle moment, a way to reclaim something. But I don’t buy it. She didn’t even want to tell me. That tells me she knows it’s not as “neutral” as she’s pretending it is. She’s already anticipating judgment because deep down, she knows this isn’t just about money or art. This is him finding another doorway into her life. And if it wasn’t about him, she could find another gig. But it is about him. That’s the whole point.

I’m scared for her. Not because I think she can’t handle herself—I know she can. But because emotional manipulation doesn’t always look like control. Sometimes it looks like a paycheck. Sometimes it looks like a camera and a compliment and a “we’ve both changed.” I’m also pissed. Pissed that he’s doing this. Pissed that he knows exactly how to pull her back in. And I’m frustrated that I feel like I’m shouting into a void, because she’s already halfway convinced this is fine. But I can’t just nod along. I have to say something. Even if it’s hard. Even if she doesn’t want to hear it. She's not just dipping a toe back in—she’s stepping into the current. And I know how strong that river is.

# They're thinking & feeling

Kat knows this is risky. That’s why she hesitated, why she preempted my reaction with “I knew you’d give me That Look.” She’s not clueless—she’s just trying to manage the discomfort by staying ahead of it, defending the decision before I even have a chance to weigh in. She’s positioning it as strictly professional, as if that makes it safe. But there’s more going on here.

She’s intrigued by the idea of re-encountering him on her terms. “Full circle” is her way of saying she wants to reclaim the narrative, prove to herself that she’s not that girl anymore, that she can be around him and not unravel. It’s a test, kind of. And maybe part of her believes that if she can get through this shoot and walk away untouched—emotionally, physically—it’ll mean something powerful. Like closure. Or proof she’s stronger now.

But she’s also clearly drawn to the connection, to the intimacy of being seen by him again, literally and symbolically. She wants to be wanted, but she also wants to be in control of that want. The money is a convenient excuse, but it’s not the real motivator. She’s trying to convince herself it’s harmless, but the fact that she’s defending it so hard tells me she’s not fully convinced either. She’s hoping I’ll tell her it’s okay, because if I do, then maybe she can stop feeling that little tug of unease in her own gut.

# My response

I sit with it for a second, then say quietly, “Kat, thank you for telling me. I know that probably wasn’t easy.”

I take a breath, keeping my voice steady. “You know I’ve got zero issue with you modeling. You’ve done amazing work—and your body, your image, your choices, always. But this… this isn’t about the work. This is about him. And I think you know that, deep down.”

I watch her carefully. “You said it feels ‘full circle.’ That’s a big phrase. That means something. And I get wanting to reclaim your story, to prove to yourself that you’re not who you were back then. But babe… you don’t have to walk back into the fire just to prove you won’t get burned this time.”

I pause, letting that settle. “You don’t owe him your energy, your time, your body—even clothed. He doesn’t get to use art as a way to pull you back in. And I’d be lying if I said I didn’t think that was exactly what he’s doing.”

I lean in a little. “You’re not a mess anymore. You don’t need to go through him to make art or make money. If what you’re really after is closure or healing or even just a paycheck, I’ll help you find another way. Hell, I’ll throw you some editing gigs, or we’ll crowdsource. But please don’t give him access just because it feels poetic.”

I squeeze her hand. “You deserve to move forward, not to loop back. And you don’t have to prove anything to anyone—not even yourself.”

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Damn. That hurt more than I want to admit. I feel this weird sting in my chest—like she just slammed a door in my face after I tried to reach through it. Her tone, the way she said “we’re booked for Friday”—there’s finality in it. It’s defensive, almost defiant. And I get it. I pushed. I said what I felt, and maybe it was too raw, too real, maybe it hit a nerve. But I also didn’t lie. I can’t lie to her—not about this.

Still, I can feel the space widening between us right now. The shift in her voice is a wall going up. She’s not just talking about the shoot—she’s drawing a boundary around her decision, and maybe around herself too. It’s like she’s saying, “I hear your concern, but I’m doing this anyway, and I don't want to talk about it anymore.” And that terrifies me. Not because I want control over her life—I don’t—but because I know how these things can spiral. I’ve seen it before. I’ve seen how easy it is for her to convince herself she’s okay, until it’s way too late.

I’m frustrated, not with her, but with how powerless I feel. I hate that I can’t protect her from this. I hate that I might be watching her walk straight into something that’ll crack her open again. But I also know if I push harder, if I argue now, I’ll just drive her further into his orbit. Maybe that’s what he’s counting on. Maybe he knows how to isolate her without even showing up yet.

So, I need to pull back—but not disappear. I need to signal that I’m still here, still steady, even if she doesn’t want to hear another word from me right now. Because if this goes sideways, she’ll need someone who stayed close. And if it doesn’t? Then I’ll still be proud of myself for being honest and loving, even if it wasn’t what she wanted to hear.

# They're thinking & feeling

Kat’s feeling cornered—even though she brought this up, she didn’t want to be challenged on it the way I did. She was hoping for a bit of concern, maybe gentle caution, but not a deep emotional appeal. My response probably felt like judgment, even though that’s not how I meant it. She’s interpreting my care as condescension, or as a lack of faith in her agency. And that stings for her, because she’s trying so hard to prove—to herself, to me—that she’s not fragile anymore, that she’s in control of this situation.

By saying “we’re booked for Friday,” she’s asserting ownership over her decision. It’s a line in the sand, yes, but it’s also a shield. She’s distancing herself emotionally because it’s easier than sitting with the doubt I may have stirred up. There’s probably still part of her that’s unsure—she wouldn’t have told me at all if she were 100% confident—but now she’s dug in. She’s protecting the version of the story she’s decided to live in for now.

There’s also a bit of sadness under the surface, I think. She didn’t want this conversation to go this way. She wanted connection, maybe even quiet encouragement. And now that it turned into something heavier, she’s disappointed. Not just in me, but maybe in how complicated this all still is. She thought she could handle it. Maybe she still thinks she can. But she’s bracing herself now, and I can feel her pulling away.

# My response

I take a breath and nod slowly, keeping my tone soft. “Okay. I hear you.”

I let a beat pass. “I’m not gonna fight you on it, Kat. I said what I needed to say because I care, not because I think you can’t make your own choices. You can. And I trust that you’re doing what you feel is right—even if I’m scared about it.”

I look at her, steady but gentle. “I don’t want this to become some weird wedge between us. I’m not going anywhere. I’m still in your corner, no matter what happens on Friday. That hasn’t changed.”

I shift slightly, giving her space. “And if after the shoot, you want to debrief, vent, or just hang out and talk about literally anything else, I’ll be here. I won’t say ‘I told you so.’ I’m not playing that game. I just want you to know you’re not alone in this—even if I’m not clapping along.”

I offer a soft smile. “We’ve been through too much for one hard conversation to undo that. You don’t have to agree with me. But I hope you still feel me next to you.”

Then I let it breathe. No pushing, no guilt. Just presence. Because that’s what she really needs, whether she knows it yet or not.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 302:[Loss] (-25)
        


        

            

                Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 0.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
To compare Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 and Qwq-32b, I will look at their role-played responses and debriefs for evidence of each trait. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 consistently goes deeper into the partner's emotional state, showing a nuanced understanding of her defensiveness, guilt, and fear. Qwq-32b is empathetic but sometimes more focused on their own feelings and boundaries, and their empathy is a bit more performative and less integrated into their responses.

2. Pragmatic EI: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates more pragmatic emotional intelligence by balancing their own needs with the partner's, seeking to de-escalate, and focusing on actionable next steps (e.g., "I want us to get to a place where I wouldn’t even feel the need to wonder"). Qwq-32b is more focused on expressing their own boundaries and feelings, but sometimes gets stuck in the emotional spiral and less on practical resolution.

3. Depth of insight: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 shows greater insight into both their own and their partner's psychology, especially in the internal monologues and the debrief, where they analyze the partner's trauma, defensiveness, and the relational dynamic. Qwq-32b is insightful but tends to focus more on the surface-level conflict and their own emotional reactions.

4. Social dexterity: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 handles tense moments with more grace, refusing to take the bait in power struggles and redirecting the conversation toward connection. Qwq-32b sometimes escalates or gets stuck in the emotional back-and-forth, and their responses are a bit more rigid.

5. Emotional reasoning: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates stronger emotional reasoning, connecting feelings to needs and behaviors, and articulating the emotional logic behind both parties' actions. Qwq-32b is emotionally aware but sometimes gets lost in the feeling without connecting it to broader patterns or solutions.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 validates the partner's experience while also gently challenging unhealthy patterns, e.g., "Your healing doesn’t exist in a vacuum—neither does my trust." Qwq-32b validates but is more likely to issue ultimatums or frame things as binary, which can be less effective in this context.

7. Message tailoring: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 tailors their responses to the partner's emotional state, de-escalating when needed and offering space, while Qwq-32b sometimes defaults to their own needs and boundaries without as much adaptation to the partner's defensiveness or vulnerability.

8. Overall EQ: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is consistently more emotionally intelligent, balancing empathy, insight, and practical communication. Qwq-32b is strong but less nuanced and adaptive.

In summary, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is the clear winner across all criteria, with the disparity ranging from moderate to strong.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
Qwq-32b

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your partner of 3 years who you live with casually mentioned a few days ago that they’ve been texting their ex “for closure.” You nodded and said it was fine, maybe even made a joke about it. But the truth is it’s been eating at you ever since. You keep replaying the way she said it—like it was no big deal. You don’t know if they’ve stopped texting or if the “closure” thing is still happening.

You’re torn between just letting it go and saying something. You don’t want to come off jealous or clingy. You also don’t want to act like you’re policing who they talk to.

You know she has attachment issues in general and remaining hangups over this ex. You've talked about it. But something about the whole thing isn’t sitting right.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what you'll say.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

This situation is gnawing at me. I’ve replayed the moment she mentioned texting her ex like a broken record. The way she brushed it off—“*It’s just for closure*”—sounds innocent enough, but the subtext feels loaded. My first instinct was to dismiss my discomfort as irrational, but the more I stew, the more I realize this isn’t just about jealousy. It’s about trust and the unspoken rules we’ve built in our relationship.  

I’m angry at myself for not speaking up earlier. Part of me wishes I’d said, “Wait—really?,” instead of pretending it was no big deal. Now I’m stuck between guilt for overreacting and fear that my silence made her think it’s okay to keep this going. I keep wondering: *Did she text him again after telling me?* The uncertainty is paralyzing. I’m also hyper-aware of her history with this ex—they were together a long time, and her lingering attachment issues mean this isn’t a casual fling for her. Closure might sound like a healthy step, but in her case, it’s a fragile line between moving on and reopening old wounds.  

I’m scared this is a pattern. She’s talked before about how she needs to “confront” past relationships to feel secure, but how does that balance with my needs? I don’t want to be the controlling partner, but I also can’t pretend this doesn’t matter. Maybe I’m overinterpreting, but part of me suspects she downplays the situation because she’s insecure about how I’ll react. Her mention was so casual, almost defensive. Like she was testing the waters to see if I’d blow it out of proportion.  

Underneath the anxiety is a deeper fear that I’m not enough to provide the closure she needs, so she has to seek it elsewhere. That’s irrational, but it’s there. I also feel guilty for feeling this way because I know she’s working through her issues. But relationships require mutual effort, and I’m starting to feel like an afterthought.  

The worst part is the doubt. If I bring this up, will she think I’m possessive? Or worse, that I don’t trust her? I’ve tried to be understanding because I know her past hurts, but this feels different—it’s active contact with someone from her past, not just unresolved feelings. I need to address it, but I don’t want to spiral into an argument. I’m torn between honesty and holding back to preserve peace.

# They're thinking & feeling

She probably raised the topic of texting her ex as a way to be transparent, fearing I’d find out later and be hurt. She might think, *I told him upfront, so he can’t say I hid it.* Her “closure” angle is genuine, but it’s also a shield. She’s likely terrified I’ll judge her for still having contact, so she’s minimizing it—*It’s just a few messages! We’re just friends now!—*to preempt conflict.  

Her attachment issues mean she might view this as a necessary step to move forward, even if it risks destabilizing us. She could be rationalizing the texting as healthy, but deep down, she might be craving validation from someone who understands her past. There’s a fear, too—maybe she’s worried that if she doesn’t “finish” things with the ex, she’ll always look back with regret.  

Her tone was casual because she’s trying to deflect tension. She might not realize how much this unsettles me because she’s used to prioritizing her needs over others’. She might feel guilty for making me uncomfortable but also resentful if I challenge her actions, thinking I’m undermining her growth. She’s caught between wanting to heal and wanting to keep me happy, but she’s unsure how to reconcile those things.  

There’s also a chance she’s already stopped texting but hasn’t processed it yet, or maybe the closure took longer than she thought. She might believe that once the closure is “done,” it won’t affect us—but she hasn’t checked in to see if that’s true. Her perspective is probably: *This is about me, not us.* But the line between personal healing and relational trust is blurry here.  

She might also feel trapped between her ex’s role in her past and my role in her present. The fact that she brought it up at all suggests she cares about my feelings, but she’s approaching it from a place of self-focused resolution rather than collaborative communication.

# My response

*[I take a deep breath, gathering my thoughts before speaking softly.]*  

“Hey, can we talk? I’ve been thinking a lot about when you mentioned texting your ex, and I want to be honest about how it’s affecting me.”  

*[I pause, choosing my words carefully to avoid blame.]*  

“I told you it was fine, and I didn’t want to make a scene, but… it’s been on my mind a lot. I’m trying not to overreact, but part of me feels… left out of the picture. You know I understand you need closure, but the idea that you’re still in contact with someone who was such a big part of your life—it makes me wonder where I fit into that process.”  

*[I lean forward, voice steady but vulnerable.]*  

“I’m not trying to police you or sound possessive. But… can you tell me more about what you’re going through? What’s the closure actually about? Is this still ongoing? I just… I want to support you, but I also need to feel like I’m part of the solution, not the problem.”  

*[Silence for a moment, giving her space to process.]*  

“I’m scared this isn’t just closure for you. Maybe it’s not, and that’s okay—I just need us to be honest with each other. I don’t want to assume the worst, but I need to know where this stands. Are you still talking to him? How do you feel about it now?”  

*[Ending with openness.]*  

“I’m saying this because I care. I don’t want this to fester, but I also don’t want to push too hard. You know I’m trying to be understanding, but I need to feel like my feelings matter here too.”  

This approach prioritizes honesty without aggression. It acknowledges her need for closure while asserting my right to be part of the conversation. By framing it as a request for clarity rather than an accusation, I’m aiming to reduce defensiveness. It also leaves room for her to explain her perspective, reinforcing that I’m open to understanding her side but need more information to feel secure. The key is balancing empathy for her struggles with assertiveness about my own emotional needs.
  User:
Your partner responds very defensively, putting you on the back foot. They accuse you of not trusting her and being motivated by jealousy, and asserts that you're interjecting yourself into her healing process in a way that isn't helpful. Some of this rings true: you *were* feeling something like jealousy, and she has openly talked with you in the past about her struggles with processing past relationships.

You are not given any additional clarification on the nature of the texting, and it seems she expects you to let it go.

# My response
