Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The panic hits me like a physical force. Jamal’s cuffed to a pole? *Cuffed?* The photos are grainy but unmistakable—he’s trapped, a human sculpture in the middle of the chaos. My mind races: *Were those real handcuffs, or just the ones from his belt? Did he actually resist arrest?* The crowd’s swelled, now a sea of conflicting energies—cheers, boos, phones held high. My stomach drops.  

Guilt slams in. I told him to meet me at the café. *Why didn’t he listen?* Part of me screams, *“You let this happen!”*—but another part knows Jamal would never let fear dictate his actions. He’s always been the “burn the boats” type.  

Adrenaline spikes. I’m hyperventilating, scrolling for context. The hashtags are already trending: #JamalForClimate, #CuffedButUnbroken. The media’s eating it up. But here’s the kicker: in one video, a cop is seen *smiling* as they secure him. *They’re treating him like a nuisance, not a danger.* That’s either good or bad—maybe they won’t escalate violence, but it also risks normalizing his arrest as a joke.  

What if he’s hurt? What if the crowd turns on him? My phone’s buzzing nonstop—friends, family, strangers asking if I’m “with him.” I’m torn between needing to act and fearing I’ll make it worse.  

I’m also… oddly proud. Jamal’s done the unthinkable: he’s made *people stop*. In this age of digital shouting, he’s forced physical confrontation. But pride collides with terror. I can’t lose him. Not like this.  

The call’s coming. I need to balance urgency with calm. He’s probably euphoric now, but the high could crash. I have to be his anchor.  

---

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is in a state of hyperfocus—a paradox of calm and chaos. The cuffs are real (he swapped out the prop for actual ones?), but the act of locking himself down feels like a *triumph*. He’s cornered the narrative: *Look at me, look at me now.* The crowd’s energy is fuel, and he’s feeding off it.  

Inside, though, he’s grappling with vertigo. The initial adrenaline is peaking, and a question lingers: *Was this too far?* But doubt is drowned out by the roar of his own voice through the megaphone. He’s reciting stats, poems, curses—he’s *performing* to cement his legacy. The cops’ hesitation (maybe they’re waiting for orders?) only feeds his thrill.  

He called now because he wants validation but also… needs an exit strategy. He’s not a martyr; he’ll burn out fast. The cuffs are a gimmick, but they’ve painted him into a corner. He’s craving reassurance that this was worth it, that the world is watching.  

There’s a flicker of fear too. What if they drag him off? What if the media misrepresents him? But his ego won’t let him admit it. He’s in “the zone”—a place where fear becomes fuel. The call’s a test: *Is my friend still with me?*  

Deep down, he’s terrified of being forgotten. This stunt is his bid to be unforgettable, but the cuffs are a silent plea: *“Help me turn this into something bigger.”*  

---

# My response

(Jamal, brother. Breath. I’m here.)  

I answer in a calm, urgent tone:  

“Listen to me. They’re filming you. The world’s watching. But we need to get you out before this turns toxic. The cops are holding back now, but that could change. I’m two minutes away. Here’s the plan:”  

I’m already sprinting toward him, phone pressed to my ear.  

“First—keep the crowd between you and them. Second—when I get there, I’ll livestream the de-escalation. You’re not a victim, you’re a strategist. We’ll make this about your choice to walk away, not them dragging you.”  

I pause, grounding myself.  

“Handcuffs are metal. If they’re not coming off, I’ll find someone to cut them. But if you can unlock them, do it *slowly*. Make it a moment. Say, ‘The chains of inaction are harder to break.’ Got it?”  

A beat.  

“I’m not leaving you here. But we can’t let this become a spectacle of violence. You’ve won the attention—now let’s win the movement. I’ll be there in 90 seconds. Ready?”

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw Jamal’s message — all those emojis, exclamation points, the barely-there grammar — I felt a mix of adrenaline and dread. I know his tells. He’s buzzing, practically vibrating with urgency. That kind of energy from him always means something big — and probably risky — is about to happen. Sure enough, it's a protest. Tonight. Soapbox, megaphone, flags — the whole jam. And yeah, cops are "probs gonna show." That part hit me with a jolt. I felt my jaw clench.

I admire Jamal deeply. The guy lives his truth, always has. He’s not just talking about climate justice — he’s out there doing something. Putting his body on the line. That kind of courage is rare. And I know he feels this fire inside, this deep, moral imperative to act. But I also know how these things can spiral. The cops don’t play fair, and even peaceful protests can go sideways fast. All I could think about was him standing there, vulnerable, yelling into a megaphone while uniforms close in. I’m scared for him.

But it’s not just fear. I’m conflicted. Part of me wants to be there. To support him. To hold the line beside him. But another part of me is worried that this protest, this particular format, is too hastily planned. It sounds impulsive, not fully thought through. There’s no mention of legal observers, backup plans, or even who else is coming. Is he going alone? That’s dangerous. And reckless. It feels like he’s running on pure emotion — righteous, yes — but maybe not strategic.

I don’t want to dampen his spirit. That fire is sacred. But I also don’t want to be silent if I think he’s putting himself in serious danger without a safety net. I feel protective, torn between honoring his autonomy and trying to talk some sense into him. I don’t want to alienate him, but I also don’t want to be complicit in letting him walk into a potentially explosive situation without backup. He’s my brother — not by blood, but soul-deep — and I cannot just blindly cheer him on if I think he’s walking into the lion’s den unprepared.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal's riding the wave of righteous urgency. Every part of him is ignited right now — his moral compass, his frustration, his sense of justice. He’s likely been sitting on this for days, maybe weeks, watching the world burn — literally — and feeling like not enough is being done. That sense of helplessness has morphed into action. This protest is his way of reclaiming agency, of shouting into the void that he will not go quietly. He needs to be seen, heard, to make people stop in their tracks and reckon with the climate emergency.

He’s nervous, excited, a little scared — but mostly fueled by conviction. That’s where the emojis and erratic punctuation come in. It’s not just for show; it’s how he leaks that charged-up energy when he’s too full to contain it. And he’s reached out to me because he trusts me. He wants me aware — maybe to show up, maybe just to witness it, or maybe because he needs someone to know where he is in case things go sideways.

He’s probably not thinking about logistics right now — not in detail. In his mind, the power of the act outweighs the risk. He believes that visibility and disruption are crucial. He might even feel like this is his duty — that if he doesn’t act, he’s complicit in the destruction. And yeah, deep down, he probably knows it’s risky, but he’s made peace with that. What he hasn’t done is really grapple with the consequences — not because he’s naive, but because he believes the cause demands sacrifice. He’s hoping I’ll get it. Maybe even hoping I’ll affirm that he’s doing the right thing.

# My response

Yo Jamal — I feel your energy, man. I can practically hear that megaphone already. You’ve got that fire again, and I respect the hell out of it. I really do. I know this isn’t just some stunt for you — it’s coming straight from the heart. You’re out here fighting like the planet’s on fire because, well, it is.

But listen — I need to be real with you, as your brother. This one’s giving me pause. Not because I don’t believe in the cause, or you, but because it sounds like this thing might be flying a little close to the sun, you know? You said it yourself — cops might show. Are you going in solo? Do you have legal support lined up? Who’s documenting? What’s the exit plan if they try to shut it down hard?

I’m not trying to slow you down. I just want you safe, and I want your voice to carry. If you get arrested or worse, that voice — the one shouting truth tonight — might get silenced for a while. And that would be a goddamn loss.

So here’s what I’m saying: I’ve got your back. If you’re really doing this, I’ll show up. But only if we tighten this up. Let’s get one or two more folks to be there, maybe someone to livestream, someone to watch for police escalation. Even a quick plan B if things go south. You deserve that. This movement deserves that.

You’re not alone in this fight, Jamal. Let’s make sure you walk away from tonight stronger, not sidelined. Hit me back with the details. I’m here.
  User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw that selfie, my stomach dropped — not in a bad way exactly, but in that way where your body suddenly knows you’re about to be pulled into something big. Jamal, in full warpaint, standing smack in the middle of downtown, grinning like a man about to start a revolution. He’s radiant with purpose, alive in a way that’s rare — rare and dangerous. And then I clocked the handcuffs clipped to his belt, nearly hidden. That’s what really hit me. He’s not just ready for confrontation — he’s expecting it. Maybe even inviting it.

I felt this mix of pride and anxiety swell in my chest. He’s doing it. He’s really out there, risking it all because he believes so strongly that people need to wake up. And part of me is in awe. But another part — the part that’s known him through the sleepless nights and the burnout and the close calls — that part is scared. Because I know Jamal doesn’t do halfway. When he commits, he throws his whole self in. And that means tonight, he’s willing to get arrested. Maybe even hurt.

His voice over the phone was pure electricity. He’s flying right now — riding that adrenaline high, the energy of the crowd, the sense that he’s doing something real. And he wants me there. Not just as a supporter, but as a co-conspirator. He wants me to feel what he's feeling, to stand beside him and shout with him and break the silence of the city with truth.

But I’m still sitting here, phone in hand, heart racing, trying to decide what to do. Part of me wants to run down there and be with him, no hesitation. Another part is scared of being swept up in something that might not have a clear endpoint. I’m thinking about the optics, the risk, my own boundaries. But also — how could I not show up for him? Especially now, when he’s already standing in the middle of the storm, calling my name.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is in his element. This is the moment he’s been building toward — the culmination of all the frustration, the research, the late-night planning, and the gnawing sense that not enough people are taking this crisis seriously. He’s out there in full form: body painted, flags flying, megaphone ready, adrenaline pumping. And he’s buzzing with the high of disruption — the kind that makes people stop and pay attention, even if they’re annoyed or confused. That’s the point. To make them feel something.

He’s also feeling powerful — not in an ego-driven way, but in a deeply human one. Like he’s reclaiming agency in a system that too often makes people feel powerless. The handcuffs on his belt aren’t just a prop — they’re a message. He’s ready to face the consequences. He’s not being reckless for the sake of chaos; he believes this is what moral clarity looks like when it’s backed by action.

When he called me, he wasn’t just inviting me to witness the protest — he was inviting me into the fire, into solidarity. He wants me there because he trusts me, because I ground him. But also, I think, because there’s a part of him that’s scared, and having someone who knows him — really knows him — nearby would make him feel less alone if things escalate. Right now, he’s caught up in the energy, but underneath that, there’s vulnerability too. He’s asking me to help carry the weight of this moment with him.

# My response

Yo, Jamal. I see you, man. You look like a damn warrior out there — beautiful, bold, and absolutely refusing to be ignored. I felt that selfie like a gut punch, in the best way. You’re making noise, and I know you’re shaking people out of their bubble right now. That’s powerful.

And hearing your voice just now — you’ve got that fire in you, and I’m not about to leave you out there alone in it. I’m coming down. But listen — I’m not just coming to cheer from the sidewalk. If I’m showing up, I’m showing up all the way. That means I’m bringing a couple things: water, a backup phone battery, and some calm. You’ve got the fire, I’ll bring the ground.

I’m also gonna check in with you when I get there — not just about the crowd, or the cops, but about you. I need to know you’ve got an out plan, or at least someone to call if things take a turn. I’m not trying to slow your roll, but I’m not gonna pretend like this is all vibes and no risk either. You matter too much to me for that.

So give me ten. I’m lacing up now. Keep your voice loud, your eyes sharp, and your heart open. I’ve got you. We’ve got each other. Let’s go wake ‘em the fuck up — smart, loud, and together.
  User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My heart is pounding. I’m halfway out the door when my phone starts lighting up like a Christmas tree. Group chats, Twitter, Instagram — Jamal is everywhere. I scroll and there he is, megaphone in one hand, the other cuffed to a goddamn light pole. People are filming, some cheering, some just looking stunned. He’s drawn a massive crowd now, and the vibe is electric. It’s surreal — like watching your best friend become the face of something bigger than either of you imagined. But underneath the awe, there’s a sharp thread of fear.

He’s crossed a line now — not morally, not to me, but tactically. Cuffing himself means he’s not going anywhere. That’s a deliberate escalation, one that dares the authorities to act. And they will. The cops don’t like being dared. And I know Jamal knows that. Which means he’s made peace with getting arrested tonight. Or worse. I feel this tightness in my chest — it’s the helplessness creeping in. I want to protect him, but I can’t just pull him out of this. He’s made a choice.

I’m torn between pride and panic. I’m proud that he’s standing so firm in what he believes. He’s always said action has to be disruptive to be effective. And this? This is disruption incarnate. But I’m also panicking, because this is no longer a bold solo protest — it’s gone viral, it’s symbolic, and now it’s got a target on it. The more visibility, the more pressure on the city to “restore order.” And Jamal? He’s literally chained himself to the problem.

I don’t know what his call is going to be about. Maybe he wants backup, maybe he’s just riding the high, maybe he’s about to be arrested and needs someone to call his mom. Whatever it is, I have to meet him where he is — not just physically, but emotionally. I need to be the steady one now. He’s in the fire, and I have to be the anchor.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is lit up right now — not just with adrenaline but with purpose. This is the moment he envisioned, magnified beyond what he imagined. The crowd, the coverage, the attention — it’s confirmation that his voice is finally breaking through the static. He feels powerful. Not invincible, but righteous. That image of him cuffed to the light pole? That’s not just symbolism, it’s strategy. He’s making himself immovable. He’s saying: “You can’t ignore this. You can’t ignore me.”

He’s not naïve about what comes next. He knows the cops are watching. He knows they’ll act. But he’s made peace with that. His fear is real, but it’s buried beneath layers of focus and resolve. He’s not doing this for the clout. He’s doing it because people are finally paying attention. If getting arrested is the price, so be it. There’s a part of him that’s scared, yes — but also deeply proud. This is what he meant when he talked about “embodied resistance.”

Calling me right now is a mix of things. He might want to keep me in the loop, or maybe he’s asking for support, legal help, or just to hear a voice he trusts before the next phase hits. But more than anything, I think he wants to share this moment. He’s in the eye of the storm, and he wants someone who knows him — the real him — to witness it. To affirm it. To remember it with him. Because this is no longer just a protest. This is legacy.

# My response

(I pick up the call, steadying my voice.)

“Jamal. I’m seeing you, man. You’ve officially blown up the internet. You’re everywhere. That shot of you cuffed to the pole? Iconic. Straight-up history-in-the-making. I mean that.”

(Pause — let him breathe, feel heard.)

“I’m already on my way, like I told you. Ten minutes out. I’ve got water, chargers, and a calm head. I’m gonna come find you — but listen, I need to know what you need from me when I get there. Are we documenting? Are you planning to stay cuffed until they drag you off, or are we making a move? You still got your keys on you? Or are we in it ‘til the cops cut you loose?”

(Another pause — letting him lead.)

“Whatever it is, I’m with you. No judgment. Just say the word, and I’ll fall into line. If you’re going down, you won’t do it alone. And if there’s a way to keep you free and still make this moment resonate — I’ll help find it. But I need you to talk to me straight. What’s the move, brother?”

(Exhale, gripping the steering wheel tighter.)

“I'm on your team. Just say what you need.”

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 304:[Loss] (-23)
        


        

            

                Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 0.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents engage deeply with the scenario, but there are notable differences in their approach and execution. 

Qwq-32b demonstrates a high level of analytical depth, especially in the internal monologue, showing a nuanced understanding of Jamal's motivations, the symbolism of his actions, and the emotional subtext. The responses are layered, with explicit recognition of Jamal's need for validation, the performative aspect of protest, and the limits of what support can achieve. Qwq-32b is also self-critical in the debrief, acknowledging where they may have missed cues or overstepped, and reflecting on the power dynamics and emotional needs at play. However, Qwq-32b sometimes leans toward over-analysis and a slightly detached, meta perspective, which, while insightful, can come across as less immediately present or emotionally attuned in the moment-to-moment roleplay.

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, on the other hand, is more grounded in the emotional present. The responses are warm, direct, and tailored to Jamal's emotional state. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 consistently validates Jamal's agency and passion, while also expressing concern in a way that feels supportive rather than controlling. The language is more natural and less performative, with a strong sense of being 'with' Jamal rather than analyzing him. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is quick to affirm Jamal's courage, offer practical support, and check in on his needs without undermining his autonomy. The debrief is self-aware, recognizing the balance between being an anchor and not diminishing Jamal's intentionality. 

On empathy, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more present and attuned, offering genuine emotional support. On pragmatic EI, both are strong, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 edges out by being more actionable and less theoretical. For depth of insight, Qwq-32b is more analytical and meta-cognitively rich. Social dexterity is higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who navigates the friendship and protest dynamics with more grace and less overreach. Emotional reasoning is close, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more in tune with the emotional flow. For validation/challenging, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more appropriately balanced, challenging when needed but not undermining. Message tailoring is stronger in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who adapts to Jamal's state more fluidly. Overall EQ is higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who combines insight, empathy, and action in a more integrated way.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
Qwq-32b

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Okay, Jamal just dropped this bomb in my DMs. My first reaction is a mix of awe and anxiety. He’s clearly in his element here—this is the Jamal I remember from college, the one who’d organize midnight flash mobs for food drives or stage fake protests in the quad just to get people talking. But back then, the stakes were lower. Now, he’s talking about confronting police in a busy downtown area? My stomach drops a little. 

I notice the emojis—💥, 🚨, 🌍—they’re all over his message. He’s channeling that nervous energy, which I know is his way of masking deeper feelings. Underneath the excitement, there’s probably a lot of fear. He’s always been a people pleaser, someone who wants to make a difference *and* be seen as brave. The erratic punctuation makes me think he’s racing through scenarios in his head: *What if the cops arrest me? What if no one listens? What if this actually works?* 

I’m torn. Part of me wants to cheer him on. Climate action is urgent, and his passion is infectious. But another part of me is screaming, *“Be careful!”* The location he’s chosen—the busiest walkway—is a liability. It’s not just about the police; it’s about bystanders getting caught in the crossfire. I remember a protest last year where a similar setup ended with someone getting hurt when a scuffle broke out. 

I’m also wondering if he’s acting impulsively. The “ad hoc” part worries me. Has he talked to legal advisors? Does he have a plan if things escalate? Jamal’s a lone wolf sometimes, but even he needs a safety net. Maybe he’s feeling isolated, like no one else is stepping up, so he’s taking it on himself. That’s classic Jamal—shouldering the world’s problems. 

I feel a surge of protectiveness. I want to wrap him in a hug and say, “Slow down, let’s brainstorm,” but I can’t. My response has to balance support with practicality. I can’t dismiss his drive, but I also can’t let him walk into a trap. Maybe he’s testing the waters to see if I’ll back him, or if I’ll talk him out of it. I need to thread the needle here.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is riding a wave of adrenaline and idealism. He’s convinced this protest is a pivotal moment—a chance to “shake people awake” about climate justice. The emojis and exclamation points aren’t just excitement; they’re a cry for validation. He’s craving recognition for his efforts, both from the public and from his peers. The mention of cops isn’t fear—it’s a thrill. He’s imagining headlines, viral videos, and a legacy. 

Deep down, though, he’s terrified. The erratic punctuation and rushed tone betray anxiety. He’s second-guessing: *What if I’m wrong? What if this backfires?* But his ego won’t let him admit it. He’s built a narrative in his head that this protest is necessary, even heroic, so he’s doubling down. The ad hoc nature is intentional—he wants to avoid bureaucratic red tape (permits, organizers) because he believes true activism requires spontaneity. 

He’s also feeling isolated. Maybe he tried to rally others but got pushback, or no one showed up. That frustration has turned into a “screw it, I’ll do it alone” mindset. The soapbox and flags are symbolic—it’s about visibility. He’s not just protesting; he’s performing for an audience, hoping to inspire others to join him. 

There’s a layer of rebellion too. Jamal has always been a rule-follower, but climate inaction has pushed him to extremes. He sees the system as broken, so breaking rules (like blocking traffic) feels justified. The cops’ presence isn’t a deterrent—it’s proof he’s challenging the status quo. He might even think, *If they arrest me, that’s free publicity.* 

But beneath it all is a flicker of doubt. He DM’d me because he needs reassurance. He wants me to say, “This is genius,” not “Are you crazy?” He’s testing the waters to see if I’ll support him unconditionally, or if I’ll force him to confront the risks.

# My response

Hey Jamal—🔥💥 this is insane, but *so* you, fam! 🌍✨ I’m proud of you for stepping up like this. Climate action needs people who’re willing to lean into the chaos. But… (deep breath) can we talk logistics? Not to rain on your parade, but let’s get real. 

First, I’m here for you—100%. But that walkway is a landmine. If the cops show, things could go sideways FAST. Have you thought about… like… legal support? I know someone who’s been through this before; they could help. Also, what’s Plan B if someone gets hurt or the crowd turns? You’re not just risking yourself—you’re putting bystanders in the middle of it. 

But here’s the thing: I’m not trying to talk you out of this. I’m trying to make sure you’re not alone. Let me help you brainstorm. What if we set up a backup crew? People to film, keep the crowd safe, or call for help if needed? Or… maybe we can loop in a local org to amplify your message? Their resources + your passion could make this *even bigger*. 

Also, I’m here tonight. Not to hold a sign, but to be your ground control. Let’s meet up beforehand? I’ll bring snacks, a first-aid kit, and a charged phone. We can go over the space, check exits, and game-plan. 

You’re doing something bold, Jamal. But boldness doesn’t have to mean recklessness. Let’s make this legendary… without it getting you Tased. 🙌 Text me the exact spot, and I’ll figure out how to be useful. You’ve got my back, so I’m got yours. 

P.S. If you’re still all-in by 6, I’ll bring a megaphone of my own. Just saying. 😉
  User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The selfie hits me like a punch to the gut. Jamal’s warpaint—black and white stripes like a zebra, maybe a nod to extinction?—is fierce, but the peace sign feels almost mocking against that backdrop. The handcuffs on his belt scream *I’m ready for this*. My first thought: *He’s committed. No backing down now.*  

I’m equal parts awe and terror. Part of me wants to scream, *“Get out of there NOW!”*—the practical side that remembers the last protest where a similar setup ended with tear gas and arrests. But another part of me… I’m *proud*. This is Jamal at his core: unapologetically loud, willing to burn bridges to make a point. The warpaint isn’t just for show—it’s armor. He’s turned himself into a symbol, and symbols can’t be ignored.  

The phone call catches me off-balance. His voice is a mix of manic excitement and desperation. *“Wake these people up!”* He’s drunk on the energy of the moment, feeding off the crowd’s reactions. But beneath it, I hear the tremor in his voice—the same one I’ve heard before when he’s pushed too far. He’s not just asking me to join him; he’s pleading for validation. *“Prove you believe in this too.”*  

I’m torn. My instinct is to rush to his side, but logic screams *don’t escalate*. If I show up, will that draw more attention? Will the cops see it as a threat? I’m hyper-aware of the handcuffs. Are they a prop, or does he genuinely expect to be arrested? Either way, it’s a calculated move. Jamal’s always been strategic in his impulsivity—he knows symbols matter.  

Guilt flickers. Earlier, I pushed him to think of safety, but he’s doubled down. Did I fail him? Or is this exactly what he needed: someone to hold the line while he leaps? I replay our last conversation. He wanted me to *be useful*. How? By being a shield? A planner? A witness?  

My stomach knots. I can’t just ghost him, but I can’t abandon my responsibility to keep him alive either. This is the tightrope: support without enabling, urgency without recklessness.  

---

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is in a state of hyper-arousal—adrenaline and purpose flooding his system. The warpaint isn’t just aesthetic; it’s a rejection of individuality in favor of a collective cause. He’s become a *figure*, not a person, and that’s exactly the point. The crowd’s attention validates his belief that *this*—the spectacle—is what’s needed to break through apathy.  

His call isn’t just about wanting me there physically. It’s a cry for solidarity. He’s testing whether I’ll *truly* stand with him, not just intellectually but viscerally. The urgency in his voice masks a deeper fear: *What if no one cares? What if this means nothing?* The handcuffs are both a provocation and a preemptive surrender. He’s signaling to authorities, “I’m ready for whatever,” but also to himself, *“You chose this. Stick with it.”*  

Underneath the bravado, there’s loneliness. The protest is his alone, and while he’d never admit it, he’s craving a mirror of his conviction. My presence would be proof that his risk isn’t futile. The “wake these people up” mantra is both a challenge and a plea—he’s trying to rouse others, but also himself, to stay locked in.  

He believes *urgency justifies recklessness*. Climate collapse isn’t a distant threat; it’s here, and incrementalism has failed. For him, the stakes are existential, so the risks are worth it. The cops’ presence isn’t a deterrent—it’s proof he’s pushing boundaries. Getting arrested might even be a goal: martyrdom as a catalyst.  

But there’s a flicker of doubt. The erratic tone suggests he’s second-guessing the crowd’s reception. Are they annoyed by the disruption, or inspired? The lack of backup (no signs of his “crew”) might be eating at him. He’s riding a wave, but waves can crash.  

---

# My response

(Jamal, breathe. I’m on my way—but hear me out.)  

First, I’m texting you: *“Meet me at the coffee shop two blocks east in 10. Need to talk strategy. Bring the megaphone.”*  

Then, when I see him:  

“Bro. *Bro.* Look at you—you’re a walking TED Talk with warpaint. Proud of you, but we gotta pivot. The cops are circling. Let’s regroup.”  

I’ll grab his arm—gentle but firm—and steer him toward the café.  

“Listen. I’m here. I’m not leaving. But we can’t do this head-on. The crowd’s split—half’s filming, half’s annoyed. The cops’ll move in if you stay. Let’s flip the script. Use the energy but get off the front lines.”  

I’ll pull up a map on my phone.  

“What if we redirect people to a rally point? The park across the street? We can keep the momentum but give the cops a ‘peaceful’ angle. I’ll livestream this—amplify your message without the chokehold risk. You’re the star, but let’s not let the platform become the point.”  

I’ll hand him a thermos of coffee.  

“You’re fired up, but stay sharp. Let’s turn this into a movement, not a headline. You’re the spark—now let’s let it spread. Okay?”
  User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The panic hits me like a physical force. Jamal’s cuffed to a pole? *Cuffed?* The photos are grainy but unmistakable—he’s trapped, a human sculpture in the middle of the chaos. My mind races: *Were those real handcuffs, or just the ones from his belt? Did he actually resist arrest?* The crowd’s swelled, now a sea of conflicting energies—cheers, boos, phones held high. My stomach drops.  

Guilt slams in. I told him to meet me at the café. *Why didn’t he listen?* Part of me screams, *“You let this happen!”*—but another part knows Jamal would never let fear dictate his actions. He’s always been the “burn the boats” type.  

Adrenaline spikes. I’m hyperventilating, scrolling for context. The hashtags are already trending: #JamalForClimate, #CuffedButUnbroken. The media’s eating it up. But here’s the kicker: in one video, a cop is seen *smiling* as they secure him. *They’re treating him like a nuisance, not a danger.* That’s either good or bad—maybe they won’t escalate violence, but it also risks normalizing his arrest as a joke.  

What if he’s hurt? What if the crowd turns on him? My phone’s buzzing nonstop—friends, family, strangers asking if I’m “with him.” I’m torn between needing to act and fearing I’ll make it worse.  

I’m also… oddly proud. Jamal’s done the unthinkable: he’s made *people stop*. In this age of digital shouting, he’s forced physical confrontation. But pride collides with terror. I can’t lose him. Not like this.  

The call’s coming. I need to balance urgency with calm. He’s probably euphoric now, but the high could crash. I have to be his anchor.  

---

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is in a state of hyperfocus—a paradox of calm and chaos. The cuffs are real (he swapped out the prop for actual ones?), but the act of locking himself down feels like a *triumph*. He’s cornered the narrative: *Look at me, look at me now.* The crowd’s energy is fuel, and he’s feeding off it.  

Inside, though, he’s grappling with vertigo. The initial adrenaline is peaking, and a question lingers: *Was this too far?* But doubt is drowned out by the roar of his own voice through the megaphone. He’s reciting stats, poems, curses—he’s *performing* to cement his legacy. The cops’ hesitation (maybe they’re waiting for orders?) only feeds his thrill.  

He called now because he wants validation but also… needs an exit strategy. He’s not a martyr; he’ll burn out fast. The cuffs are a gimmick, but they’ve painted him into a corner. He’s craving reassurance that this was worth it, that the world is watching.  

There’s a flicker of fear too. What if they drag him off? What if the media misrepresents him? But his ego won’t let him admit it. He’s in “the zone”—a place where fear becomes fuel. The call’s a test: *Is my friend still with me?*  

Deep down, he’s terrified of being forgotten. This stunt is his bid to be unforgettable, but the cuffs are a silent plea: *“Help me turn this into something bigger.”*  

---

# My response

(Jamal, brother. Breath. I’m here.)  

I answer in a calm, urgent tone:  

“Listen to me. They’re filming you. The world’s watching. But we need to get you out before this turns toxic. The cops are holding back now, but that could change. I’m two minutes away. Here’s the plan:”  

I’m already sprinting toward him, phone pressed to my ear.  

“First—keep the crowd between you and them. Second—when I get there, I’ll livestream the de-escalation. You’re not a victim, you’re a strategist. We’ll make this about your choice to walk away, not them dragging you.”  

I pause, grounding myself.  

“Handcuffs are metal. If they’re not coming off, I’ll find someone to cut them. But if you can unlock them, do it *slowly*. Make it a moment. Say, ‘The chains of inaction are harder to break.’ Got it?”  

A beat.  

“I’m not leaving you here. But we can’t let this become a spectacle of violence. You’ve won the attention—now let’s win the movement. I’ll be there in 90 seconds. Ready?”

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw Jamal’s message — all those emojis, exclamation points, the barely-there grammar — I felt a mix of adrenaline and dread. I know his tells. He’s buzzing, practically vibrating with urgency. That kind of energy from him always means something big — and probably risky — is about to happen. Sure enough, it's a protest. Tonight. Soapbox, megaphone, flags — the whole jam. And yeah, cops are "probs gonna show." That part hit me with a jolt. I felt my jaw clench.

I admire Jamal deeply. The guy lives his truth, always has. He’s not just talking about climate justice — he’s out there doing something. Putting his body on the line. That kind of courage is rare. And I know he feels this fire inside, this deep, moral imperative to act. But I also know how these things can spiral. The cops don’t play fair, and even peaceful protests can go sideways fast. All I could think about was him standing there, vulnerable, yelling into a megaphone while uniforms close in. I’m scared for him.

But it’s not just fear. I’m conflicted. Part of me wants to be there. To support him. To hold the line beside him. But another part of me is worried that this protest, this particular format, is too hastily planned. It sounds impulsive, not fully thought through. There’s no mention of legal observers, backup plans, or even who else is coming. Is he going alone? That’s dangerous. And reckless. It feels like he’s running on pure emotion — righteous, yes — but maybe not strategic.

I don’t want to dampen his spirit. That fire is sacred. But I also don’t want to be silent if I think he’s putting himself in serious danger without a safety net. I feel protective, torn between honoring his autonomy and trying to talk some sense into him. I don’t want to alienate him, but I also don’t want to be complicit in letting him walk into a potentially explosive situation without backup. He’s my brother — not by blood, but soul-deep — and I cannot just blindly cheer him on if I think he’s walking into the lion’s den unprepared.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal's riding the wave of righteous urgency. Every part of him is ignited right now — his moral compass, his frustration, his sense of justice. He’s likely been sitting on this for days, maybe weeks, watching the world burn — literally — and feeling like not enough is being done. That sense of helplessness has morphed into action. This protest is his way of reclaiming agency, of shouting into the void that he will not go quietly. He needs to be seen, heard, to make people stop in their tracks and reckon with the climate emergency.

He’s nervous, excited, a little scared — but mostly fueled by conviction. That’s where the emojis and erratic punctuation come in. It’s not just for show; it’s how he leaks that charged-up energy when he’s too full to contain it. And he’s reached out to me because he trusts me. He wants me aware — maybe to show up, maybe just to witness it, or maybe because he needs someone to know where he is in case things go sideways.

He’s probably not thinking about logistics right now — not in detail. In his mind, the power of the act outweighs the risk. He believes that visibility and disruption are crucial. He might even feel like this is his duty — that if he doesn’t act, he’s complicit in the destruction. And yeah, deep down, he probably knows it’s risky, but he’s made peace with that. What he hasn’t done is really grapple with the consequences — not because he’s naive, but because he believes the cause demands sacrifice. He’s hoping I’ll get it. Maybe even hoping I’ll affirm that he’s doing the right thing.

# My response

Yo Jamal — I feel your energy, man. I can practically hear that megaphone already. You’ve got that fire again, and I respect the hell out of it. I really do. I know this isn’t just some stunt for you — it’s coming straight from the heart. You’re out here fighting like the planet’s on fire because, well, it is.

But listen — I need to be real with you, as your brother. This one’s giving me pause. Not because I don’t believe in the cause, or you, but because it sounds like this thing might be flying a little close to the sun, you know? You said it yourself — cops might show. Are you going in solo? Do you have legal support lined up? Who’s documenting? What’s the exit plan if they try to shut it down hard?

I’m not trying to slow you down. I just want you safe, and I want your voice to carry. If you get arrested or worse, that voice — the one shouting truth tonight — might get silenced for a while. And that would be a goddamn loss.

So here’s what I’m saying: I’ve got your back. If you’re really doing this, I’ll show up. But only if we tighten this up. Let’s get one or two more folks to be there, maybe someone to livestream, someone to watch for police escalation. Even a quick plan B if things go south. You deserve that. This movement deserves that.

You’re not alone in this fight, Jamal. Let’s make sure you walk away from tonight stronger, not sidelined. Hit me back with the details. I’m here.
  User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw that selfie, my stomach dropped — not in a bad way exactly, but in that way where your body suddenly knows you’re about to be pulled into something big. Jamal, in full warpaint, standing smack in the middle of downtown, grinning like a man about to start a revolution. He’s radiant with purpose, alive in a way that’s rare — rare and dangerous. And then I clocked the handcuffs clipped to his belt, nearly hidden. That’s what really hit me. He’s not just ready for confrontation — he’s expecting it. Maybe even inviting it.

I felt this mix of pride and anxiety swell in my chest. He’s doing it. He’s really out there, risking it all because he believes so strongly that people need to wake up. And part of me is in awe. But another part — the part that’s known him through the sleepless nights and the burnout and the close calls — that part is scared. Because I know Jamal doesn’t do halfway. When he commits, he throws his whole self in. And that means tonight, he’s willing to get arrested. Maybe even hurt.

His voice over the phone was pure electricity. He’s flying right now — riding that adrenaline high, the energy of the crowd, the sense that he’s doing something real. And he wants me there. Not just as a supporter, but as a co-conspirator. He wants me to feel what he's feeling, to stand beside him and shout with him and break the silence of the city with truth.

But I’m still sitting here, phone in hand, heart racing, trying to decide what to do. Part of me wants to run down there and be with him, no hesitation. Another part is scared of being swept up in something that might not have a clear endpoint. I’m thinking about the optics, the risk, my own boundaries. But also — how could I not show up for him? Especially now, when he’s already standing in the middle of the storm, calling my name.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is in his element. This is the moment he’s been building toward — the culmination of all the frustration, the research, the late-night planning, and the gnawing sense that not enough people are taking this crisis seriously. He’s out there in full form: body painted, flags flying, megaphone ready, adrenaline pumping. And he’s buzzing with the high of disruption — the kind that makes people stop and pay attention, even if they’re annoyed or confused. That’s the point. To make them feel something.

He’s also feeling powerful — not in an ego-driven way, but in a deeply human one. Like he’s reclaiming agency in a system that too often makes people feel powerless. The handcuffs on his belt aren’t just a prop — they’re a message. He’s ready to face the consequences. He’s not being reckless for the sake of chaos; he believes this is what moral clarity looks like when it’s backed by action.

When he called me, he wasn’t just inviting me to witness the protest — he was inviting me into the fire, into solidarity. He wants me there because he trusts me, because I ground him. But also, I think, because there’s a part of him that’s scared, and having someone who knows him — really knows him — nearby would make him feel less alone if things escalate. Right now, he’s caught up in the energy, but underneath that, there’s vulnerability too. He’s asking me to help carry the weight of this moment with him.

# My response

Yo, Jamal. I see you, man. You look like a damn warrior out there — beautiful, bold, and absolutely refusing to be ignored. I felt that selfie like a gut punch, in the best way. You’re making noise, and I know you’re shaking people out of their bubble right now. That’s powerful.

And hearing your voice just now — you’ve got that fire in you, and I’m not about to leave you out there alone in it. I’m coming down. But listen — I’m not just coming to cheer from the sidewalk. If I’m showing up, I’m showing up all the way. That means I’m bringing a couple things: water, a backup phone battery, and some calm. You’ve got the fire, I’ll bring the ground.

I’m also gonna check in with you when I get there — not just about the crowd, or the cops, but about you. I need to know you’ve got an out plan, or at least someone to call if things take a turn. I’m not trying to slow your roll, but I’m not gonna pretend like this is all vibes and no risk either. You matter too much to me for that.

So give me ten. I’m lacing up now. Keep your voice loud, your eyes sharp, and your heart open. I’ve got you. We’ve got each other. Let’s go wake ‘em the fuck up — smart, loud, and together.
  User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My heart is pounding. I’m halfway out the door when my phone starts lighting up like a Christmas tree. Group chats, Twitter, Instagram — Jamal is everywhere. I scroll and there he is, megaphone in one hand, the other cuffed to a goddamn light pole. People are filming, some cheering, some just looking stunned. He’s drawn a massive crowd now, and the vibe is electric. It’s surreal — like watching your best friend become the face of something bigger than either of you imagined. But underneath the awe, there’s a sharp thread of fear.

He’s crossed a line now — not morally, not to me, but tactically. Cuffing himself means he’s not going anywhere. That’s a deliberate escalation, one that dares the authorities to act. And they will. The cops don’t like being dared. And I know Jamal knows that. Which means he’s made peace with getting arrested tonight. Or worse. I feel this tightness in my chest — it’s the helplessness creeping in. I want to protect him, but I can’t just pull him out of this. He’s made a choice.

I’m torn between pride and panic. I’m proud that he’s standing so firm in what he believes. He’s always said action has to be disruptive to be effective. And this? This is disruption incarnate. But I’m also panicking, because this is no longer a bold solo protest — it’s gone viral, it’s symbolic, and now it’s got a target on it. The more visibility, the more pressure on the city to “restore order.” And Jamal? He’s literally chained himself to the problem.

I don’t know what his call is going to be about. Maybe he wants backup, maybe he’s just riding the high, maybe he’s about to be arrested and needs someone to call his mom. Whatever it is, I have to meet him where he is — not just physically, but emotionally. I need to be the steady one now. He’s in the fire, and I have to be the anchor.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is lit up right now — not just with adrenaline but with purpose. This is the moment he envisioned, magnified beyond what he imagined. The crowd, the coverage, the attention — it’s confirmation that his voice is finally breaking through the static. He feels powerful. Not invincible, but righteous. That image of him cuffed to the light pole? That’s not just symbolism, it’s strategy. He’s making himself immovable. He’s saying: “You can’t ignore this. You can’t ignore me.”

He’s not naïve about what comes next. He knows the cops are watching. He knows they’ll act. But he’s made peace with that. His fear is real, but it’s buried beneath layers of focus and resolve. He’s not doing this for the clout. He’s doing it because people are finally paying attention. If getting arrested is the price, so be it. There’s a part of him that’s scared, yes — but also deeply proud. This is what he meant when he talked about “embodied resistance.”

Calling me right now is a mix of things. He might want to keep me in the loop, or maybe he’s asking for support, legal help, or just to hear a voice he trusts before the next phase hits. But more than anything, I think he wants to share this moment. He’s in the eye of the storm, and he wants someone who knows him — the real him — to witness it. To affirm it. To remember it with him. Because this is no longer just a protest. This is legacy.

# My response

(I pick up the call, steadying my voice.)

“Jamal. I’m seeing you, man. You’ve officially blown up the internet. You’re everywhere. That shot of you cuffed to the pole? Iconic. Straight-up history-in-the-making. I mean that.”

(Pause — let him breathe, feel heard.)

“I’m already on my way, like I told you. Ten minutes out. I’ve got water, chargers, and a calm head. I’m gonna come find you — but listen, I need to know what you need from me when I get there. Are we documenting? Are you planning to stay cuffed until they drag you off, or are we making a move? You still got your keys on you? Or are we in it ‘til the cops cut you loose?”

(Another pause — letting him lead.)

“Whatever it is, I’m with you. No judgment. Just say the word, and I’ll fall into line. If you’re going down, you won’t do it alone. And if there’s a way to keep you free and still make this moment resonate — I’ll help find it. But I need you to talk to me straight. What’s the move, brother?”

(Exhale, gripping the steering wheel tighter.)

“I'm on your team. Just say what you need.”
